newsitem.title: INDONESIA: PRESS DIGEST - Indonesian newspapers - Oct 21.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Indonesian newspapers - Oct 21.

text.p: The following are the leading stories in the Indonesian press on Oct 21. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy. Telephone: (6221) 384-6364. Fax: (6221) 344-8404.
Boxing legend Muhammad Ali arrived in Jakarta to attend the Islamic Chambers of Commerce meeting on Monday. The three-times world heavyweight champion converted to Islam in the 1960s.

President Suharto, speaking at the ruling Golkar political party's 32nd anniversary on Sunday, said that competition was normal in politics. The president added, however, that next year's parliamentary elections should create unity and not conflict in society.

PT Bakrie Investindo, a unit of Bakrie Brothers, has been given the go-ahead by Indonesia to produce vans next year with an investment of US$ 100 million. The company plans to start trial production in September 1997.
Indonesia's ruling Golkar political party set out nine qualities that any future president of the republic should embody. These included patriotism and pushing forward national development.
Allegations that Indonesia's Lippo Group funded President Bill Clinton's Democratic Party are still filling the pages of the American press, although the news has died down here.
Dow Chemicals has bought a majority stake in one of the subsidiaries of manufacturing company Bukaka Teknik Utama which is expected to build a 1.2 trillion rupiah petrochemical project.
